Converting CO2 into high-value chemicals is an essential way to mitigate greenhouse impact and realize sustainable utilization of resources. In this work, the COF materials named X-QCOF (X = OH, OCH3) were synthesized by a three-component Povarov reaction, followed by chemical grafting of hydroxyl‑functionalized ionic liquid into the COFs neutral backbone via quaternization to obtain the hybrid materials IL-X-QCOF (X = OH, OCH3). The resultant IL-X-QCOF can efficiently catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides in the absence of metals, additives and solvents. Among them, IL-OH-QCOF exhibits a yield of 97.2% of cyclochloroallyl carbonate with a high turnover frequency (TOF) value of 217.7. The inherent high specific surface area of the COF-based materials promotes mass transfer efficiency, and meanwhile the abundant hydroxyl groups and bromine anions occurring in the backbone create excellent catalytic effect. Attributed to the chemical grafting approach, the product yield keeps over 90% when IL-OH-QCOF is reused for 6 cycles. According to predictions, the atmospheric CO2 concentration will climb to 590 ppm by the year 2100, which would cause a 1.9 °C increase in global temperatures [1,2]. The gradual elevation of atmospheric CO2 concentration is the major factor responsible for global warming, which exerts a series of adverse effects [3]. However, CO2, as a cheap and easily available C1 resource, is an important raw material for the synthesis of numerous valuable chemical industrial products [4–9]. Among them, the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides stands out with a 100% atom economy. Additionally, the product cyclic carbonate is an important chemical product, which can be used in many fields such as lithium ion batteries, pharmaceuticals, fine chemicals, and so on, offering an attractive application prospect [10,11]. Given the thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness of CO2 [12], it is necessary to explore efficient catalysts for promoting CO2 conversion. The difficulty in separating products and catalysts in homogeneous catalytic systems and the difficulty in recovering and reusing catalysts have limited their wide application [13,14]. While some typical heterogeneous catalysts such as zeolites and MOFs require solvents [15]. The problem of metal contamination is another unavoidable consequence of MOFs [16]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop new heterogeneous catalysts for cycloaddition reactions. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are porous crystalline materials linked by covalent bonds based on the principle of dynamic covalent chemistry (DCC) [17]. Due to the characteristics of high specific surface area, tunable structure, high stability and ease of modification, COFs have been widely used in the domains of catalysis, sensing, and energy storage [18–20]. COFs can prevent metal contamination and have adjustable structure and functionality, which can foster the CO2 cycloaddition reaction via the selection of building blocks. But the typical COF catalysts need to add cocatalysts [21,22]. Novel COFs can be exploited by modification to improve the catalytic performance. According to the mechanism study of the reaction between CO2 and epoxides, the existence of hydrogen bond donors, such as hydroxyl and carboxyl groups, as well as nucleophilic groups (typically containing halogen ions), can aid in the activation of epoxides, which in turn promotes the epoxide addition reaction [23]. Ionic liquids (ILs) are a kind of molten salts containing anions and cations, and the anions in ILs are often halogen ions, which can be used to catalyze cycloaddition reactions. However, the high viscosity and homogeneous nature of ILs have hindered their further development [24]. Integrating ILs moiety containing nucleophilic groups into the structures of COFs to build IL-functionalized COFs can improve the architecture of COFs and avoid the use of cocatalysts [25,26]. IL-functionalized COFs combine the merits of ILs being CO2-philic and possessing nucleophilic moieties with the advantages of heterogeneous, highly stable, and abundant pores of COFs, which is expected to achieve a better performance of heterogeneous catalysis under the solvent-free environment. Herein, we synthesized the triazine COF materials (OH-QCOF, OCH3-QCOF) in one-pot based on the multicomponent Povarov reaction. The synthesized COF backbone features rich nitrogen heteroatoms, which can interact with CO2 and realize the enrichment of CO2 at the catalytic site. Meanwhile, X-QCOF has an imidazole moiety that can be covalently grafted to ionic liquids by facile postmodification. Subsequently, IL-X-QCOF was prepared by in-situ incorporation of bromine anion on the COF platform via a one-step quaternization reaction (Scheme 1 ). Among them, the as-synthesized IL-OH-QCOF exhibits excellent catalytic performance in cycloaddition conversion attributed to the abundant hydroxyl groups, nitrogen heteroatoms and evenly dispersed nucleophilic bromide ions, reaching the highest yield of 97.2%. It is worth noting that the catalytic process is metal-free and without the addition of any solvents or cocatalysts. The chemical grafting approach enables strong force between the ionic liquid and COFs support, thereby reducing the loss of ionic liquids and improving the catalytic stability. Moreover, the heterogeneity of IL-OH-QCOF allows it for recycling and reuse. As far as we know, this is the first example of hydroxyl‑functionalized ionic liquid being introduced into triazine COFs for CO2 cycloaddition. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials 1-vinylimidazole (VIM), 2,4,6-tris(4-aminophenyl)-1,3,5-triazine (TAPT), 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalaldehyde (DHTA) and 2,5-dimethoxyterephthalaldehyde (DMTA) were purchased from Leyan (Shanghai, China). Yb(OTf)3, 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyano-1,4-benzoquinone (DDQ) and 2-bromoethanol were supplied from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). Acetonitrile, tetrahydrofuran (THF), ethyl acetate and epichlorohydrin were obtained from Meryer (Shanghai, China). Carbon dioxide (CO2, 99.995%) and nitrogen (N2, 99.999%) were provided by Liufang (Tianjin, China). All reagents were used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of X-QCOF X-QCOF was synthesized as follows. The monomers TAPT (0.16 mmol, 56.7 mg), DHTA (0.24 mmol, 39.9 mg), and VIM (2.40 mmol, 220 μL) were added into a 25 mL Pyrex tube filled with solvent acetonitrile (3 mL). The monomers were fully dispersed after 20 min of sonication. The catalyst Yb(OTf)3 (0.024 mmol, 14.9 mg) and oxidant DDQ (0.03 mmol, 6.8 mg) were added and the resulting suspension was further sonicated. The Pyrex tube was then subjected to three freeze-pump-thaw cycles under 77 K liquid nitrogen. The sealed tube was kept in an oven at 80 °C for 72 h. After the reaction, the mixture was separated by centrifugation and washed several times with tetrahydrofuran. The mixture was dried under vacuum at 120 °C overnight to provide a brick red solid, namely OH-QCOF. OCH3-QCOF was synthesized in a similar way by replacing DHTA with DMTA. 2.3 Synthesis of IL-X-QCOF OH-QCOF (163.8 mg), 2-bromoethanol (50 μL) and acetonitrile (10 mL) were added to a round-bottomed flask, and the mixture was refluxed and stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. After being cooled down to room temperature, the precipitated material was collected by centrifugation and washed with ethyl acetate several times. Finally, the mixture was dried under vacuum at 80 °C overnight to obtain IL-OH-QCOF. Similarly, OCH3-QCOF (172.2 mg), 2-bromoethanol (50 μL) and acetonitrile (10 mL) were added to a flask and placed at 80 °C for 24 h. Once the reaction was completed, the isolated precipitated material was washed several times with ethyl acetate. Finally, the mixture was dried under vacuum at 80 °C overnight to obtain IL-OCH3-QCOF. 2.4 Synthesis of ionic liquid The ionic liquid 1-(2-hydroxyethyl)-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([Hemim][Br]) was synthesized as follows. 1-Methylimidazole (0.05 mol, 4.105 g) and 2-bromoethanol (0.06 mol, 7.498 g) were dissolved in 20 mL of toluene. The mixture was heated and refluxed at 80 °C for 24 h while being surrounded by a nitrogen atmosphere, then washed with anhydrous ether after spin evaporation. Finally, it was dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h to obtain the white solid, designated as [Hemim][Br]. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO‑d 6): δ = 9.13 (s, 1H), 7.73 (dt, 2H), 5.16 (s, 1H), 4.22 (t, 2H), 3.87 (s, 3H), 3.71 (t, 2H). 2.5 Cycloaddition reaction test The cycloaddition reaction of carbon dioxide with epichlorohydrin was used as the model reaction. In a typical process, the reactant epichlorohydrin (4 g) and catalyst IL-X-QCOF (120 mg) were first added to the high-pressure reactor. After sealing the reactor, condensate was passed around the reactor. The gas line was connected and the device was checked for gas tightness and carbon dioxide gas was passed into the reactor several times to clean and evacuate the air from the reactor. Then, when the carbon dioxide gas was continuously inputted until the pressure was 2.5 MPa, the main valve, the pressure-reducing valve and the input valve were closed and the gas line was cut off. The reactor was heated and stirred at 120 °C for 12 h. At the end of the reaction, the bleeder valve was unlocked to gradually release the gas in the kettle when the temperature was cooled down to room temperature. Then the catalyst and reaction product were separated and the product yield was analyzed using gas chromatography (GC). In order to evaluate the recyclability of the material, the collected catalyst was washed with ethyl acetate and dried under vacuum at 120 °C overnight for direct use in catalyzing the following reaction. 2.6 Characterizations The crystal structures of X-QCOF and IL-X-QCOF were determined by a Smartlab X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku, Japan) with a scanning speed of 4°/min and a step size of 0.01° over a range of 2–30°. The imidazole group on the COF backbone in the first modification step could be used as a reactive group for the subsequent process, followed by quaternization with 2-bromoethanol to obtain IL-OH-QCOF. This made it possible to covalently graft hydroxyl ionic liquid onto the COF pore walls. To exemplify the feasibility of the synthesis procedure, OCH3-QCOF and IL-OCH3-QCOF were also synthesized in an analogous manner by substituting the aldehyde monomer from DHTA to DMTA in the COF synthesis. Fig. 1 (a) demonstrates the XRD patterns of OH-QCOF and IL-OH-QCOF. The findings show that the prepared OH-QCOF has a stronger diffraction peak at 2.80°, which is associated with the (100) facet. The weaker diffraction peaks at 4.79°, 5.78°, and 7.41° correspond to the (110), (200), and (210) facets respectively. The AA eclipsed stacking mode of OH-QCOF was simulated, which has a P3 space group with cell parameters of a = b = 36.8737 Å, c = 3.7358 Å, α = β = 90°, and γ = 120°. The experimental results of the XRD patterns of OH-QCOF are in good agreement with AA eclipsed stacking simulation results. After grafting, the XRD peak positions of IL-OH-QCOF become 2.86°, 4.8°, 5.77°, and 7.44°, corresponding to (100), (110), (200), and (210) facets, which are slightly shifted to higher angles compared with the ungrafted OH-QCOF. This is due to the introduction of ionic liquid occupying the pores of COF, which makes the pores narrower. Compared to OCH3-QCOF and IL-OCH3-QCOF (Fig. S1(a)), OH-QCOF and IL-OH-QCOF with hydroxyl functional groups on the backbone have higher crystallinity, which may be explained by the presence of hydroxyl groups inhibiting the free rotation of the conformation through OH···N = C hydrogen bonding interactions [27]. From the FT-IR spectra (Figs. 1(b), S1(b)), it can be seen that the C = C characteristic peak of VIM (1647 cm-1), the C = O characteristic peak of DHTA (1663 cm-1), and the NH characteristic peaks of TAPT (3458 cm-1, 3318 cm-1) disappear after the reaction. Meanwhile, the emerging characteristic peaks in X-QCOF can be attributed to the formation of quinolone [28], suggesting that the condensation reaction has been successfully conducted. After further quaternization, the characteristic peaks of IL-X-QCOF are still maintained, meaning that the incorporation of ionic liquids in the quaternization process has not significantly altered the structures. Nevertheless, the introduction of ionic liquid is demonstrated by the appearance of new characteristic vibrations of IL-OH-QCOF at 2927 cm-1 (-CH2) and IL-OCH3-QCOF at 3380 cm-1 (-OH). As shown in Figs. 2 and S2, X-QCOF is a coral-like shape formed by particle agglomeration both before and after grafting the ionic liquid, and there is no significant change in its morphology. It indicates that the ionic liquid is mainly introduced into the inner pores of X-QCOF rather than outside the pores [29]. The elemental distribution images of IL-X-QCOF show that the C, N, O, and Br elements are evenly distributed, and the presence of the Br element further proves the successful incorporation of ionic liquid. TEM images of the COF-based materials further demonstrate their high crystallinity. As shown in Figs. 3 and S3, the TEM diagrams of X-QCOF and IL-X-QCOF reveal that both of them exhibit stacked nanosheets. This is due to the stronger π-π stacking interaction between neighboring layers of COF materials. In addition, there are clear lattice fringes in IL-OH-QCOF (Fig. S4) with a parallel line distance of about 0.372 nm corresponding to the (001) facet diffraction of IL-OH-QCOF, which indicates that the quaternization-modified COF material keeps ordered crystalline structure. In addition, the bromine content in the typical sample IL-OH-QCOF was 0.134 mmol/g measured by ICP-MS. N2 adsorption-desorption tests performed at 77 K were used to examine the pore characteristics of the COF-based materials. As can be seen from Figs. 4 (a) and S5 (a), all samples present typical type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms, signifying the mesoporous structure of the samples. The presence of hysteresis loops indicates the presence of stacked pores and slit pores. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area of OH-QCOF is 979 m2/g, and the total pore volume is 0.52 cm3/g. The BET specific surface area and the pore volume of OCH3-QCOF are slightly larger than those of OH-QCOF, which are 1318 m2/g and 0.74 cm3/g respectively. The higher specific surface area and larger pore volume provide a workable approach for the post-modification of the materials. After grafting ionic liquids by quaternization, the isothermal shapes of IL-OH-QCOF and IL-OCH3-QCOF are not obviously changed, but the specific surface area and pore volume gradually drop to 843 m2/g, 0.44 cm3/g and 686 m2/g, 0.34 cm3/g respectively. This is because the pores of the materials are partially occupied by the integrated ionic liquid. The pore size distribution plots based on NLDFT model (Figs. 4(b), S5(b)) show that X-QCOF possesses a wide mesoporous pore size range, and the decrease in the pore quantity after grafting can be ascribed to the clogging of the pore channels, which further proves the successful grafting. The thermal stability of COF-based materials was evaluated using the TGA technique. As depicted in Figs. 5 and S6, the weight loss process of X-QCOF and IL-X-QCOF can be divided into three stages. The minor weight loss within 200 °C is mainly resulted from the removal of water and organic solvent molecules adsorbed by the materials. The materials undergo a sluggish decomposition from 200 to 400 °C, which is probably associated with the intrinsic nature of the quinoline-linkage chemical structure, and similar phenomena have been observed [30]. The COF-based materials' exceptional thermal stability is demonstrated by the fact that the skeleton of the materials fails to start to gradually collapse until temperatures reach 400 °C. After grafting ionic liquids, IL-X-QCOF exhibits a tendency to lose weight that is akin to that of X-QCOF. However, IL-X-QCOF has a greater DTG peak corresponding to a higher temperature of around 400 °C and a better mass retention, implying the interactions between IL and carrier after grafting ionic liquids enhance the thermal stability to a certain extent [31]. All the samples show no obvious weight loss under 200 °C, which suggests their potential applicability in the subsequent catalytic process of the cycloaddition reaction. XPS analysis was used to determine the elemental composition and chemical state of the COF-based materials. IL-OH-QCOF was selected as a typical sample for evaluation. As seen in Fig. 6 , the appearance of N 1 s, O 1 s, and Br 3d peaks proves the presence of N, O, and Br elements in IL-OH-QCOF. The deconvolution of the N 1 s core-level XPS spectra results in three peaks located at 398.8 eV, 399.5 eV, and 401.3 eV, corresponding to triazine and imine nitrogen moiety, quinoline nitrogen moiety and imidazolium nitrogen (N +) moiety respectively [32–34]. The deconvolution of the O 1 s core-level XPS spectra is identified as a single peak occurring at 532.8 eV, which is assigned to the hydroxyl oxygen carried by the aldehyde monomer itself [35]. In addition, for the Br 3d spectra, it can be deconvolved to a double peak at 68.5 eV, 69.4 eV, which corresponds to Br 3d5/2 and Br 3d3/2 [36]. It means that the catalytic conversion efficiency of the cycloaddition reaction is anticipated to be substantially enhanced via the effective insertion of Br ions into the OH-QCOF framework by quaternization post-modification. 3.2 CO2 capture activity of X-QCOF and IL-X-QCOF In general, the effective adsorption of CO2 is a prerequisite for the realization of efficient conversion [37], and the enrichment of CO2 surrounding the active sites of COF-based catalysts is favorable for the promotion of cycloaddition conversion. OH-QCOF and IL-OH-QCOF were chosen as representative research objects. As displayed in Fig. 7 (a), the CO2 adsorption isotherms of OH-QCOF and IL-OH-QCOF ranging from 0 to 1 bar are tested at 273 K and 298 K. The CO2 adsorption capacities of OH-QCOF and IL-OH-QCOF at 273 K and 1 bar are 1.39 mmol/g and 1.24 mmol/g respectively. As the temperature is increased to 298 K, the CO2 adsorption quantities of OH-QCOF and IL-OH-QCOF fall to 0.97 mmol/g and 0.93 mmol/g, indicating that the adsorption is an exothermic process. The slight decrease in CO2 uptake capacity of IL-OH-QCOF compared to OH-QCOF may be attributed to the decrease in available adsorption sites [38], which results from the decrease in the BET specific surface area of the COF material after grafting ionic liquid. Furthermore, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) values for CO2 of OH-QCOF and IL-OH-QCOF have been calculated using the Clausius-Clapeyron equation coupled with the CO2 adsorption isotherms (Fig. 7(b)). The initial Qst values of OH-QCOF and IL-OH-QCOF are 16.26 kJ/mol and 14.33 kJ/mol respectively, implying that CO2 is adsorbed on the COF-based materials by physisorption (< 40 kJ/mol) [39]. Interestingly, physisorption is more widely applicable in practical catalytic applications. 3.3 Catalytic performance of X-QCOF and IL-X-QCOF The catalytic performance of COF-based materials in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epichlorohydrin was investigated without the addition of any solvent and co-catalyst. The initial reaction conditions are 120 °C, 2.5 MPa, 12 h, and a catalyst dosage of 3 wt% relative to the mass of epichlorohydrin. When IL-OH-QCOF is used as the catalyst (Table 1 , Entry 1), the yield of the cyclochloroallyl carbonate product reaches 97.2%. As a control, the target product cannot be obtained in the absence of the catalyst (Table 1, Entry 2), indicating that the presence of the catalyst is necessary for the cycloaddition reaction. The catalytic performances of the different catalysts are further explored, and it is found that a yield of > 70% can be achieved when ungrafted OH-QCOF (Table 1, Entry 3), as well as ionic liquids (Table 1, Entry 4), are used as catalysts alone. OH-QCOF has abundant -OH functional groups, whereas ionic liquid contains a large number of bromine anions, which accounts for the catalytic effect of both. Nevertheless, the catalytic capacity of the two is still significantly lower compared with IL-OH-QCOF, which demonstrates that IL-OH-QCOF, with integrated -OH functional groups and bromide ions, can play a synergistic effect. To our surprise, IL-OCH3-QCOF (Table 1, Entry 5) yields only 76.9% under the identical conditions. When the dosage of IL-OCH3-QCOF is increased to 4 wt%, the yield reaches 93.0% (Table 1, Entry 6), yet still lower than that of IL-OH-QCOF (Table 1, Entry 1). This is possibly due to the lack of -OH functional group in the material itself simultaneously with the presence of -OCH3 leading to a larger steric hindrance. Therefore, IL-OH-QCOF is selected as a suitable catalyst for the following catalytic reaction. The effects of reaction parameters including catalyst dosage, reaction temperature, CO2 pressure, and reaction time on the cycloaddition process were thoroughly investigated in detail using IL-OH-QCOF as the catalyst. The effect of catalyst dosage is first tested at 120 °C, 2.5 MPa, and 12 h. When the catalyst dosage increases from 2 wt% to 3 wt%, the yield of cyclochloroallyl carbonate rises (Fig. 8 (a)). With further increases in catalyst dosage, the reaction yield slightly declines, which can be explained by the decrease in mass transfer due to excessive catalyst dosage. Temperature plays a vital role in the cycloaddition reaction. The effect of reaction temperature is studied under catalyst dosage of 3 wt%, 2.5 MPa, and 12 h. As the reaction temperature increases from 80 °C to 120 °C, the yield improves substantially from 15.4% to 97.2%. When the temperature is further increased to 140 °C, the reaction yield increases only marginally to 99.3% (Fig. 8(b)). From the perspective of saving energy, a subsequent temperature of 120 °C is determined. Next, various initial CO2 pressures are examined at a catalyst dosage of 3 wt%, 120 °C, and 12 h. With the elevation of CO2 pressure from 1.0 MPa to 2.5 MPa, the yield of cyclochloroallyl carbonate increases from 64% to 97.2% (Fig. 8(c)). As a result, the CO2 pressure is set for further research at 2.5 MPa. Finally, the effect of reaction time is investigated. When the reaction time is prolonged from 4 h to 12 h, the yield gradually increases. Further extension to 16 h, the yield enhancement is insignificant (Fig. 8(d)). To conclude, the optimal reaction parameters when using IL-OH-QCOF as the catalyst are 3 wt% of catalyst relative to epichlorohydrin, 120 °C, 2.5 MPa, and 12 h. The yield of cyclochloroallyl carbonate is up to 97.2%. Moreover, the reaction selectivities are all close to 100% under different reaction conditions. The recyclability of the catalyst is a crucial index to measure its practical application prospect. As presented in Fig. 9 , the yield of cyclochloroallyl carbonate is still maintained over 90% after six cycles of reuse, indicating the remarkable recyclability of IL-OH-QCOF. The reused IL-OH-QCOF was characterized by XRD, FT-IR, SEM, and N2 adsorption and desorption tests (Figs. S7–S9). The crystal shape of the reused catalyst is similar to that before usage. The newly appeared peak at 1790 cm-1 of the reused IL-OH-QCOF can be attributed to the C = O bond of the product cyclic carbonate [40]. Compared to the fresh samples, the morphology of the reused catalyst shows no apparent change and remains in the form of stacked particles. Meanwhile, the BET specific surface area and total pore volume of the material are also maintained, which are 723 m2/g and 0.40 cm3/g respectively. In addition, the bromine content of IL-OH-QCOF samples after 6 cycles was 0.130 mmol/g, with no significant decrease compared to the fresh sample, further indicating the stability of the material. Table 2 summarizes the experimental results of IL-COF-based materials in catalyzing the reaction between CO2 and epichlorohydrin. Compared with the reported IL-COF hybrid materials (Entry 2, 3, 5, 6 and 7), the IL-OH-QCOF catalyst reported in this work consumes less dosage, which facilitates the reduction of the reaction cost. Meanwhile, IL-OH-QCOF takes a shorter time to catalyze the process (Entry 2, 3, 4 and 6). As a result, in solvent-free, comparable temperature and pressure conditions, IL-OH-QCOF can realize the effective catalytic cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epichlorohydrin with a lower dosage and shorter reaction time. The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated to be 217.7 h-1, demonstrating outstanding intrinsic activity compared to some IL-COF-based catalysts (Entry 5, 6 and 7). The above results indicate that IL-OH-QCOF is a promising candidate for the cycloaddition catalytic conversion process. The plausible catalytic mechanism of IL-OH-QCOF hybrid material in the cycloaddition reaction is postulated based on previous literature reports [46] (Fig. 10 ). At first, the abundant -OH functional groups in IL-OH-QCOF serve as hydrogen bond donors to weaken the CO bonds by interacting with the oxygen atoms in epichlorohydrin (step a). Next, the bromine anions in the ionic liquid moiety act as nucleophiles to attack the β-carbons of epichlorohydrin, leading to ring opening of the epoxide ring to create the oxyanion intermediates (step b). The abundance of nitrogen heteroatoms and large specific surface area of IL-OH-QCOF promote the enrichment of CO2 near the catalytic site. Then CO2 is inserted into the oxyanion intermediates to generate the carbonate ion intermediates (step c). Ultimately, the product cyclochloroallyl carbonate is formed through intramolecular ring closing (step d). 4 Conclusion To summarize, novel triazine COF materials were synthesized in one-pot by the Povarov reaction, followed by a facile postmodification via introducing hydroxyl‑functionalized ionic liquids to prepare IL-X-QCOF. IL-X-QCOF has large BET specific surface area (> 600 m2/g) and high thermal stability (thermal decomposition temperature up to 400 °C). Ionic liquid functionalization enables the catalyst to contain nucleophilic bromine anions, which avoids the necessity of cocatalysts for the reaction and facilitates CO2 fixation. Taking the cycloaddition conversion of CO2 and epichlorohydrin as a model reaction, IL-OH-QCOF as catalyst provides a yield of 97.2% of cyclochloroallyl carbonate and a TOF value of 217.7 under the optimal conditions with a catalyst dosage of 3 wt%, 120 °C, 2.5 MPa, and 12 h. The prominent catalytic performance of IL-OH-QCOF can be attributed to the synergistic catalytic effect of hydroxyl groups as the hydrogen bonding donors and bromide anions as the nucleophilic groups. Acting as a heterogeneous catalyst, IL-OH-QCOF shows great recyclability without any significant decrease in activity after 6 cycles of reuse. This study provides a facile avenue for the design of COF-based catalysts in CO2 conversion. coredata.dc:description: Converting CO2 into high-value chemicals is an essential way to mitigate greenhouse impact and realize sustainable utilization of resources. In this work, the COF materials named X-QCOF (X = OH, OCH3) were synthesized by a three-component Povarov reaction, followed by chemical grafting of hydroxyl‑functionalized ionic liquid into the COFs neutral backbone via quaternization to obtain the hybrid materials IL-X-QCOF (X = OH, OCH3). The resultant IL-X-QCOF can efficiently catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides in the absence of metals, additives and solvents. Among them, IL-OH-QCOF exhibits a yield of 97.2% of cyclochloroallyl carbonate with a high turnover frequency (TOF) value of 217.7. The inherent high specific surface area of the COF-based materials promotes mass transfer efficiency, and meanwhile the abundant hydroxyl groups and bromine anions occurring in the backbone create excellent catalytic effect. Attributed to the chemical grafting approach, the product yield keeps over 90% when IL-OH-QCOF is reused for 6 cycles.
